name: bagpipes
definition: A musical instrument having a flexible bag inflated either by a tube with valves or by bellows, a double-reed melody pipe and from one to four drone pipes.
description:
Bagpipes are a wind instrument using enclosed reeds fed from a constant reservoir of air in the form of a bag.

A set of bagpipes minimally consists of an air supply, a bag, a chanter and usually at least one drone; anyway, many bagpipes have more than one drone.

The pipes can be made from wood or plastic.

The most common method of supplying air to the bag is through blowing into a blowpipe or blowstick.

Before becoming famous in Scotland, the bagpipes had been played for possibly thousands of years in Turkey, Asia, Africa, the Persian Gulf and some places in Europe.

While commonly used in traditional music, the bagpipes have also been used in less traditional music genres such as metal, hip hop, punks, classical and rock.

facts.name: Bagpipes were banned in Scotland
facts.value: In 1560 and in 1746 the bagpipes were banned in Scotland.

facts.name: The chanter is the melody played by the piper
facts.value: The chanter is the melody pipe which can be played by the piper, while the drone or drones provide a constant note.

facts.name: Used on military ceremonies
facts.value: Canada, New Zealand, Australia, and the UK use the bagpipes today in their military ceremonies. The bagpipes are also commonly used in police services as well.

facts.name: English pipers refer to the bagpipes as 'a stand of pipes'
facts.value: English pipers tend to refer to the bagpipes as 'a stand of pipes', 'a set of pipes', or 'the pipes' as opposed to 'bagpipes'.

facts.name: Some bagpipes were made with ring caps of elephant ivory
facts.value: Some traditional bagpipes were made with ring caps of elephant ivory that makes it difficult to take the instrument to countries where ivory has been banned.

facts.name: Bagpipes have several parts including the air supply blowpipe
facts.value: Bagpipes have several parts including the air supply blowpipe, the bag, the chanter, the chanter reed, and the drone or drones.

facts.name: The Great Highland bagpipe is a double reed instrument
facts.value: The Great Highland bagpipe is classified specifically as a double reed woodwind instrument.

facts.name: Scotland the Brave is the most commonly played song
facts.value: Scotland the Brave is said to be the most commonly played song on the bagpipes.

facts.name: Bagpipes were deemed a weapon of war
facts.value: Bagpipes were deemed a weapon of war at one time because they were used to scare away enemies during battle.

facts.name: The Great Highland bagpipes gained popularity WWI and WWII
facts.value: The Scottish Great Highland bagpipes gained popularity when the British Empire expanded and included Highland military regiments, especially during WWI and WWII.

facts.name: The reed can be made from water reeds
facts.value: The reed can be made from water reeds, plastic, metal, animal antlers or brass.

facts.name: Nero played the bagpipes
facts.value: Nero, the ancient emperor of Rome, is believed to have played the bagpipes while Ancient Rome burned.

facts.name: The bag of the bagpipes can be made of a variety of materials
facts.value: The bag of the bagpipes can be made of a variety of materials. The type used often depends on the environment as they must be air-tight and water absorbent to last. Material used ranges from sheepskin, elk hide, cow hide and kangaroo hide, to Gore-Tex (substitute for animal hides).

facts.name: Oldest reference to bagpipes dates back to 1000 BC
facts.value: Although there are not many bagpipes today that existed prior to the 1800s there are a few examples that suggest they have existed since ancient times. A sculpture that dates to 1000 BC shows bagpipes. Other references to the bagpipes exist in written form dating to the 2nd century AD.
